Description: Body sherd of Chian, possibly Type A, pottery kantharos; white slip; interior glazed streaky black; part of lotus flower in added white outline with added red centres above two white lines; exterior: from top, traces of probable guilloche; two dilute lines; painted decoration consisting of sphinx (wing and part of back remaining) to right; part of pendant roundel as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: The sherd likely comes from a kantharos with two zones of animal friezes. For parallels, see Williams 1983, 169-171, fig. 12. Williams, D. ‘Aigina, Aphaia-Tempel 5. The pottery from Chios’, Archäologischer Anzeiger 1983. Lemos describes the sherd as belonging to the Group of Light-Walled Naukratis Animal Chalices. All sherds in this group are small and offer very little by way of information beyond the fact that they come from light-walled chalices. The decoration on sherds belonging to this group is also poorly or carelessly drawn (Lemos 1991, 93). Vessels in the Mature Animal Style and Type A kantharoi are contemporary.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 93, p. 259, no. 497, pl. 66)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1652) (phase 2)
